species_list: Carya, Fraxinus, Quercus, Acer, Betula, Fagus, Liriodendron, Magnolia, Nyssa, Populus
rep_number: n = 119 trees from 2011 to 2020 for HF; 321 trees from 1998 to 2003
authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: there was no consistent lengthening of Lpgs
teststatistic_where: Fig. 1 and Extended Data Figs. 3 and 4
ifyouthink_no_why: no test of GSL x growth
excellent_study: Sadly no, because they never actually test the GSL to growth link.
big_problems: Did not correlate phenology and growth; correlated something like spring phenology sensitivity (they call it CTW, see bottom right pg 554) with growth (multiple metrics)
missing_something_major: GSL x growth (they have the data)

species_list: Carya, Fraxinus, Quercus, Acer, Betula, Fagus, Liriodendron, Magnolia, Nyssa, Populus
excellent_study: See other row of data for this paper
big_problems: This is followup to their phenology x dendrometer part of the paper, they used tree rings to look at lots of correlations.

species_list: Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris, Abies alba, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Quercus petraea, Quercus pubescens
study_scale: TreeNet; 47 sites and 8 years of data
study_level: within and across years within individuals
teststatistic_where: phenology hardly contributed to explain the inter-annual variation in annual growth, whereas growth activity, particularly N daysgrowth, turned out to be the most important predictor in the LMM explaining 65% to 88% of the inter- annual variation (Table S3, Figure S8).
youthink_evidence_gslxgrowth_notsure: so many tests,  and many with covariates (photoperiod!) so hard to know
ifyes_whichendogenous: Species including ring vs. diffuse porous
excellent_study: This is a very important study for us as they have data on lots of our surrounding questions
big_problems: their 'dredge' approach the analyses is diffiucult to interpret (and yikes, photoperiod as covariate)

study_level: within individuals for < 1 year (April to October 2018)
authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: lots of duration of xylogenesis (as Y variable) with xylem cell production
youthink_evidence_gslxgrowth_notsure: no clear test, also low sample size
authorslooked_endogenousfactors_notsure: They looked at lots of 'anatomical features' and lots about early/latewood … maybe that counts?
notes: Though I realize these data are painstaking to collect
notes_specific_columns: endogenous: they think they looked at this, they write: Our study provides an eco-physiological explanation that reflects the interaction between the endogenous and environmental factors driving xylem phenology and wood production.
